title: R45725
content: The Jones Act, part of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, mandates that vessels transporting cargo between U.S. points must be U.S.-built, owned, and crewed. It protects U.S. shipyards, carriers, and sailors but is debated for increasing costs and limiting ship availability. The Jones Act has been a prominent issue in recent Congresses, linked to Puerto Rico's economic challenges, the sinking of the ship El Faro in 2015, and discussions on domestic oil and gas transportation. Its effectiveness in achieving national security goals is under scrutiny, with a call for a national maritime strategy. The Jones Act of 1920, a law requiring U.S.-built, owned, and crewed vessels for domestic cargo transport, was a restatement of a long-standing restriction dating back to 1789. In May 2018, the Office of Management and Budget sought public input on modifying or repealing federal regulations to enhance efficiency in the maritime sector. In 1789, Congress enacted laws imposing lesser duties on domestically built and owned vessels. By 1817, only U.S.-built vessels owned by U.S. citizens could register as U.S. vessels. In 1886, the prohibition on foreign-owned vessels transporting domestic cargo was extended to include passengers. The U.S. had a shipbuilding advantage due to ample timber supplies. During the late 1800s, the U.S. lost its shipbuilding advantage to Scotland and England as wooden sailing ships were replaced by iron steamships. Congress debated how to address the decline in U.S. vessels in foreign trade, with proposals for foreign-built vessels to sail under the U.S. flag. Opponents argued that higher costs of U.S. crews would hinder a resurgence in trade carried by U.S. vessels. Since 1912, the domestic build requirement has mainly applied to vessels for domestic voyages.
